for each account and region set the appropriate Newly Detected Groups Behavior, Full Managed or Lock.","complianceTag":"Dome9 Netsec"},{"name":"Detect EC2 Classic Instances that are not Configured under Virtual Private Cloud","severity":"Medium","logic":"Instance should have vpc","description":"Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) provides superior network control (compared with classic EC2) as well as additional network security capabilities (Egress traffic filtering, network ACLs...), hence are considered as the secure and recommended method to deploy AWS compute resource.","remediation":"Migrate from EC2 classic to VPCs, for example use AWS recommended steps avaliable at: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/vpc-migrate.html","complianceTag":"Dome9 Netsec"},{"name":"Security Groups must be defined under a Virtual Private Cloud","severity":"Medium","logic":"SecurityGroup where not name='default' should have vpc","description":"Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) provides superior network control (compared with classic EC2) as well as additional network security capabilities (Egress traffic filtering, network ACLs...), hence are considered as the secure and recommended method to deploy AWS compute resource.","remediation":"Migrate from EC2 classic to VPCs, for example use AWS recommended steps avaliable at: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/vpc-migrate.html \r Delete old security groups after migrating the compute resources.","complianceTag":"Dome9 Netsec"},{"name":"'default' Security Groups should not have network policies","severity":"Medium","logic":"SecurityGroup where name='default' should have inboundRules isEmpty() and outboundRules isEmpty()","description":"The VPC default security group is automatically created, can't be deleted and by default is created with a rule allowing all inbound and outbound traffic.\nAWS and Dome9's best practice is to keep the default Security Group without any rules and avoid using it. ","remediation":"Make sure the default security group is not used and has no rules defined. \nDelete all rules that exist in the default group especially the default rules allowing any inbound and outbound traffic. ","complianceTag":"Dome9 Netsec"},{"name":"Remove Unused Security Groups","severity":"Medium","logic":"SecurityGroup where name != 'default' should not have networkAssetsStats contain-all [ count = 0 ]","description":"A Security Group with no attached protected assets is an unused Security Group. It is a best practice to remove unused security group.","remediation":"Delete Unused Security Groups detected by the Dome9 Report.","complianceTag":"Dome9 Netsec"},{"name":"RDS should not have Public Interface","severity":"Medium","logic":"RDS should not have isPublic = 'true'","description":"Databases should not be accessible to the public internet and be accessed by within a VPC in a secure manner.","remediation":"Remove the public interface, follow AWS guidlines at: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonRDS/latest/UserGuide/USER_VPC.html","complianceTag":"Dome9 Netsec"},{"name":"Public Instance with service 'Cassandra' (TCP:7001) is exposed to the entire internet","severity":"High","logic":"Instance where isPublic=true and inboundRules contain [port <= 7001 and portTo >= 7001 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL')] should not have inboundRules contain [port <= 7001 and portTo >= 7001 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL') and scope isPublic() and scope='0.0.0.0/0']","description":"Databases store data that may be sensitive, protected by law, subject to regulatory requirements or compliance standards. It is highly recommended that access to data will be restricted to only the applications, services and endpoints that requires access. This rule detects network settings that my expose an instance or a database Cassandra to a too permissive network access.","remediation":"Configure your database to only allow access in internal networks and limited access scope.,\r\rIf public interface exists, remove it and limit the access scope within the VPC only to applications or instances that requires access.,\r\rSee http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/authorizing-access-to-an-instance.html,\r\r  . This rule detects network settings that my expose an instance or a database MSSQL Server to a too permissive network access.","remediation":"Configure your database to only allow access in internal networks and limited access scope.,\r\rIf public interface exists, remove it and limit the access scope within the VPC only to applications or instances that requires access.,\r\rSee http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/authorizing-access-to-an-instance.html,\r\r  . As a further protection step, Use Dome9 'Tamper Protection' (Full Protection mode) and region lock to prevent unauthorized changes to network access settings.,\r\rRefer to https://dome9-security.atlassian.net/wiki/display/DG/Edit+an+AWS+Region for more details.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"Instance with service 'Oracle DB SSL' (TCP:2484) is exposed to a wide network scope","severity":"Medium","logic":"Instance where inboundRules contain [port <= 2484 and portTo >= 2484 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL')] should not have inboundRules contain [port <= 2484 and portTo >= 2484 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL') and scope numberOfHosts() > 256 ]","description":"Databases store data that may be sensitive, protected by law, subject to regulatory requirements or compliance standards. This rule detects network settings that may expose data via unencrypted protocol over the public internet or to a too wide local scope.","remediation":"Configure your database to only allow access over encrypted protocols in internal networks.,\r\rIf public interface exists, remove it and limit the access scope within the VPC only to applications or instances that requires access.,\r\rSee http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/authorizing-access- to-an-instance.html ,\r\r . As a further protection step, Use Dome9 'Tamper Protection' (Full Protection mode) and region lock to prevent unauthorized changes to network access settings, refer to https://dome9-security.atlassian.net/wiki/display/DG/Edit+an+AWS+Region for more details.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"Instance with unencrypted Elastic search (TCP:9200) is exposed to the public internet","severity":"High","logic":"Instance where isPublic=true and inboundRules contain [port <= 9200 and portTo >= 9200 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL')] should not have inboundRules contain [port <= 9200 and portTo >= 9200 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL') and scope isPublic() and scope numberOfHosts() >= 1]","description":"Services and databases store data that may be sensitive, protected by law, subject to regulatory requirements or compliance standards. As a further protection step, Use Dome9 'Tamper Protection' (Full Protection mode) and region lock to prevent unauthorized changes to network access settings.,\r\rRefer to https://dome9-security.atlassian.net/wiki/display/DG/Edit+an+AWS+Region for more details.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"Public ELB with service 'MySQL' (TCP:3306) is exposed to the entire internet","severity":"High","logic":"ELB where isPublic=true and inboundRules contain [port <= 3306 and portTo >= 3306 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL')] should not have inboundRules contain [port <= 3306 and portTo >= 3306 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL') and scope isPublic() and scope='0.0.0.0/0']","description":"Databases store data that may be sensitive, protected by law, subject to regulatory requirements or compliance standards. As a further protection step, Use Dome9 'Tamper Protection' (Full Protection mode) and region lock to prevent unauthorized changes to network access settings.,\r\rRefer to https://dome9-security.atlassian.net/wiki/display/DG/Edit+an+AWS+Region for more details.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"Public ELB with service 'Hadoop Name Node' (TCP:9000) is exposed to a wide public network","severity":"Medium","logic":"ELB where isPublic=true and inboundRules contain [port <= 9000 and portTo >= 9000 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL')] should not have inboundRules contain [port <= 9000 and portTo >= 9000 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL') and scope isPublic() and scope numberOfHosts() > 256 and scope !='0.0.0.0/0']","description":"Databases store data that may be sensitive, protected by law, subject to regulatory requirements or compliance standards. As a further protection step, Use Dome9 'Tamper Protection' (Full Protection mode) and region lock to prevent unauthorized changes to network access settings.,\r\rRefer to https://dome9-security.atlassian.net/wiki/display/DG/Edit+an+AWS+Region for more details.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"ELB with service 'Memcached SSL' (TCP:11215) is exposed to a wide network scope","severity":"Medium","logic":"ELB where inboundRules contain [port <= 11215 and portTo >= 11215 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL')] should not have inboundRules contain [port <= 11215 and portTo >= 11215 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL') and scope numberOfHosts() > 256 ]","description":"Databases store data that may be sensitive, protected by law, subject to regulatory requirements or compliance standards. This rule detects network settings that may expose data via unencrypted protocol over the public internet or to a too wide local scope.","remediation":"Configure your database to only allow access over encrypted protocols in internal networks.,\r\rIf public interface exists, remove it and limit the access scope within the VPC only to applications or instances that requires access.,\r\rSee http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/authorizing-access- to-an-instance.html ,\r\r . In addition the root account is the most privileged AWS account, it has unrestricted access to all resources in the AWS account. Therefore It is highly recommended that the use of this account be avoided. Minimizing the use of this account and adopting the principle of least privilege for access management will reduce the risk of accidental changes and unintended disclosure of highly privileged credentials.","remediation":"Follow the instructions to ensure IAM policies are attached only to groups or roles recommendation. It also requires to Implement procedures to verify that a person or entity seeking access to electronic protected health information is the one claimed. Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) adds an extra layer of protection on top of a user name and password. With MFA enabled, when a user signs in to an AWS  website, they will be prompted for their user name and password as well as for an authentication code from their AWS MFA device. It is recommended that MFA be enabled for all accounts that have a console password.\nEnabling MFA provides increased security for console access as it requires the authenticating principal to possess a device that emits a time-sensitive key and have knowledge of a credential.","remediation":"Follow the instructions to ensure multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enabled for all IAM users that have a console password at: https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"HIPAA 164.312(e)(1)"},{"name":"Ensure credentials (with password enabled) unused for 90 days or greater are disabled","severity":"High","logic":"IamUser where passwordEnabled='true' should have passwordLastUsed after(-90, 'days')","description":"HIPAA requires to Implement technical security measures to guard against unauthorized\naccess to electronic protected health information that is being transmitted\nover an electronic communications network. AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials, such as passwords or access keys. It is recommended that all credentials that have been unused in 90 or greater days be removed or deactivated. Disabling or removing unnecessary credentials will reduce the window of opportunity for credentials associated with a compromised or abandoned account to be used.","remediation":"Follow the instructions to ensure unused for 90 days or greater are disabled at: https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"HIPAA 164.312(e)(1)"},{"name":"Ensure credentials (with first activated acccessKey) unused for 90 days or greater are disabled","severity":"High","logic":"IamUser where firstAccessKey.isActive='true' should have firstAccessKey.lastUsedDate after(-90, 'days')","description":"HIPAA requires to Implement technical security measures to guard against unauthorized\naccess to electronic protected health information that is being transmitted\nover an electronic communications network.\nAWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials, such as passwords or access keys. It also requires to Implement procedures to verify that a person or entity seeking access to electronic protected health information is the one claimed.\nAccess keys consist of an access key ID and secret access key, which are used to sign programmatic requests that you make to AWS. AWS users need their own access keys to make programmatic calls to AWS from the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI), Tools for Windows PowerShell, the AWS SDKs, or direct HTTP calls using the APIs for individual AWS services. It is recommended that all access keys be regularly rotated.\n Rotating access keys will reduce the window of opportunity for an access key that is associated with a compromised or terminated account to be used. Access keys should be rotated to ensure that data cannot be accessed with an old key which might have been lost, cracked, or stolen.","remediation":"Follow the instructions to ensure unused for 90 days or greater are disabled at: https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"HIPAA 164.312(e)(1)|HIPAA 164.312(d)"},{"name":"Ensure second access key is rotated every 90 days or less","severity":"High","logic":"IamUser where createDate before(-90, 'days') and secondAccessKey.isActive='true' should have (secondAccessKey.lastRotated after(-90, 'days') and secondAccessKey.lastUsedDate > secondAccessKey.lastRotated )","description":"HIPAA requires to Implement technical security measures to guard against unauthorized\naccess to electronic protected health information that is being transmitted\nover an electronic communications network. The recorded information includes the identity of the API caller, the time of the API call, the source IP address of the API caller, the request parameters, and the response elements returned by the AWS service. CloudTrail uses Amazon S3 for log file storage and delivery, so log files are stored durably. In addition to capturing CloudTrail logs within a specified S3 bucket for long term analysis, realtime analysis can be performed by configuring CloudTrail to send logs to CloudWatch Logs. AWS Key Management Service (KMS) is a managed service that helps create and control the encryption keys used to encrypt account data, and uses Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) to protect the security of encryption keys. AWS Key Management Service (KMS) allows customers to rotate the backing key which is key material stored within the KMS which is tied to the key ID of the Customer Created customer master key (CMK). A VPC comes with a default security group whose initial settings deny all inbound traffic, allow all outbound traffic, and allow all traffic between instances assigned to the security group. If you don't specify a security group when you launch an instance, the instance is automatically assigned to this default security group. Security groups provide stateful filtering of ingress/egress network traffic to AWS resources. It is recommended that the default security group restrict all traffic.\nConfiguring the default security group to restrict all traffic will encourage least privilege security group development and mindful placement of AWS resource into security groups which will in-turn reduce the exposure of those resources.","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"HIPAA 164.312(e)(1)"},{"name":"Secure cryptographic key storage for Instances that might run a Database.","severity":"High","logic":"Instance where (name like '%db%') or (name like '%database%' ) or (name like '%sql%' ) or (name like '%couchbase%' ) or (name like '%riak%' )  or (name like '%redis%' )  or (name like '%hbase%' )  or (name like '%oracle%' )  or (name like '%hana%' ) or (name like '%postgres%' )  or (name like '%cassandra%' )   or (name like '%hadoop%' )  or (name like '%mongo%' )  or (name like '%graph%' )  or (name like '%Neo4j%' ) should have volumes with [kmsKeyId and encrypted='true']","description":"HIPAA requires to Implement a mechanism to encrypt and decrypt electronic protected health information. It is recommended that MFA be enabled for all accounts that have a console password.","remediation":"Disable user's login that do not have active MFA","complianceTag":"IAM"},{"name":"Accounts - without enforced Password Policy","severity":"High","logic":"Iam should have passwordPolicy.enabledInAccount=true","description":"Verify that password policy is enabled for the account. PCI-DSS Section 8.2, 8.3 Verify that PCI-DSS password policy requirements are configured and enforced.","remediation":"Implement AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines for password policies in the account https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"IAM"},{"name":"IAM Users - with Inline IAM Policies applied","severity":"High","logic":"IamUser should not have inlinePolicies","description":"Inline policies are policies that are embedded directly into a single user, group, or role.\nIt is recommend to use managed policies instead of inline policies. Managed policies provide reusability, central change management, versioning and more capabilities.\nFor more information: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/access_policies_managed-vs-inline.html","remediation":"Remove the inline policies and replace them with managed policies.","complianceTag":"IAM"},{"name":"IAM Users - enabled while unused for 90 days or more","severity":"High","logic":"IamUser where passwordEnabled='true' should have passwordLastUsed after(-90, 'days')","description":"AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials, such as passwords or access keys. It is recommended that all credentials that have been unused in 90 or greater days be removed or deactivated.","remediation":"Implement AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines, section 1.3 https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"IAM"},{"name":"Accounts - with 'root' in use","severity":"High","logic":"IamUser where name like '%root%' should not have passwordLastUsed after(-90, 'days')","description":"The root account is the most privileged AWS account, it has unrestricted access to all resources in the AWS account. It is highly recommended that the use of this account be avoided. Minimizing the use of this account and adopting the principle of least privilege for access management will reduce the risk of accidental changes and unintended disclosure of highly privileged credentials.","remediation":"Follow the instructions to ensure IAM policies are attached only to groups or roles recommendation. Reference http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/best-practices.html","complianceTag":"IAM"},{"name":"S3 Buckets - without CloudTrail access logging","severity":"High","logic":"S3Bucket where policy.Statement contain [Principal.Service='cloudtrail.amazonaws.com'] should have logging.enabled='true'","description":"S3 Bucket Access Logging generates a log that contains access records for each request made to your S3 bucket. An access log record contains details about the request, such as the request type, the resources specified in the request worked, and the time and date the request was processed. It is recommended that bucket access logging be enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket. \nBy enabling S3 bucket logging on target S3 buckets, it is possible to capture all events which may affect objects within an target buckets. Configuring logs to be placed in a separate bucket allows access to log information which can be useful in security and incident response workflows.","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"S3Bucket"},{"name":"Default Security Groups - with network policies","severity":"High","logic":"SecurityGroup where name='default' should have inboundRules isEmpty() and outboundRules isEmpty()","description":"The VPC default security group is automatically created, can't be deleted and by default is created with a rule allowing all inbound and outbound traffic. \nAWS and Dome9's best practice is to keep the default Security Group without any rules and avoid using it.","remediation":"Make sure the default security group is not used and has no rules defined. \nDelete all rules that exist in the default group especially the default rules allowing any inbound and outbound traffic.","complianceTag":"NetworkSecurity"},{"name":"Security Groups - with admin ports too exposed to the public internet","severity":"High","logic":"SecurityGroup should not have inboundRules with [scope =  '0.0.0.0/0' and port in (20, 21, 22, 23, 115, 137, 138, 139, 2049, 3389)]","description":"Security groups provide stateful filtering of ingress/egress network traffic to AWS resources. It is recommended that no security group allows unrestricted ingress access to administrative ports ports.","remediation":"Delete any rules allowing unrestricted access to administrative ports - see Dome9 documentation on service related alerts: https://dome9-security.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/DG/pages/71270411/Alerts.\nUse Dome9 Dynamic Access instead: https://dome9-security.atlassian.net/wiki/display/DG/Dynamic+Access+Leasing","complianceTag":"NetworkSecurity"},{"name":"Security Groups - with SSH admin port too exposed to the public internet","severity":"High","logic":"SecurityGroup should not have inboundRules with [scope =  '0.0.0.0/0' and port<=22 and portTo>=22]","description":"Security groups provide stateful filtering of ingress/egress network traffic to AWS resources. These logs file are stored in an S3 bucket. It is recommended that policy applied to the S3 bucket that holds CloudTrail logs prevents public access","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":""},{"name":"S3 bucket access logging should be enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket","severity":"High","logic":"S3Bucket where policy.Statement contain [Principal.Service='cloudtrail.amazonaws.com'] should have logging.enabled='true'","description":"S3 Bucket Access Logging generates a log that contains access records for each request made to your S3 bucket. An access log record contains details about the request, such as the request type, the resources specified in the request worked, and the time and date the request was processed. It is recommended that bucket access logging be enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket.\nBy enabling S3 bucket logging on target S3 buckets, it is possible to capture all events which may affect objects within an target buckets. Configuring logs to be placed in a separate bucket allows access to log information which can be useful in security and incident response workflows.","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":""},{"name":"S3 bucket should have logging enabled","severity":"High","logic":"S3Bucket should have logging.enabled=true","description":"Turn on logging on all of your buckets so that you can make sure that all changes are logged and trackable.","remediation":"Turn on logging. It is recommended that MFA be enabled for all accounts that have a console password.\nEnabling MFA provides increased security for console access as it requires the authenticating principal to possess a device that emits a time-sensitive key and have knowledge of a credential.","remediation":"Follow the instructions to ensure multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enabled for all IAM users that have a console password at: https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"PCI-DSS Section 8.1.2| PCI-DSS Section 8.1.3| PCI-DSS Section 8.1.4 "},{"name":"Ensure credentials (with first activated acccessKey) unused for 90 days or greater are disabled","severity":"High","logic":"IamUser where firstAccessKey.isActive='true' should have firstAccessKey.lastUsedDate after(-90, 'days')","description":"AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials, such as passwords or access keys. It is recommended that all access keys be regularly rotated.\n Rotating access keys will reduce the window of opportunity for an access key that is associated with a compromised or terminated account to be used. It is recommended that MFA be enabled for all accounts that have a console password.\nEnabling MFA provides increased security for console access as it requires the authenticating principal to possess a device that emits a time-sensitive key and have knowledge of a credential.","remediation":"\"This control is implemented as a Config rule backed by a custom lambda function. IAM policies are the means by which privileges are granted to users, groups, or roles. It is recommended that IAM policies be applied directly to groups and roles but not users. \nAssigning privileges at the group or role level reduces the complexity of access management as the number of users grow. Reducing access management complexity may in-turn reduce opportunity for a principal to inadvertently receive or retain excessive privileges.","remediation":"This control is implemented as a Config rule backed by a custom lambda function. The Config rule  DOES NOT enforce this control by attaching IAM policies to either IAM Groups or Roles We recommend that you assign IAM Policies to either IAM Groups or IAM Roles to reduce the complexity of access management as the number of users grow. \n\nIf the Config rule reports NonCompliance, ensure IAM policies are attached only to Groups or Roles.","complianceTag":"CIS for AWS v1.0.0 Section 1.15 "},{"name":"Ensure CloudTrail is enabled in all regions","severity":"High","logic":"CloudTrail should have isMultiRegionTrail=true","description":"AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls for your account and delivers log files to you. The recorded information includes the identity of the API caller, the time of the API call, the source IP address of the API caller, the request parameters, and the response elements returned by the AWS service. CloudTrail uses Amazon S3 for log file storage and delivery, so log files are stored durably. In addition to capturing CloudTrail logs within a specified S3 bucket for long term analysis, realtime analysis can be performed by configuring CloudTrail to send logs to CloudWatch Logs. For a trail that is enabled in all regions in an account, CloudTrail sends log files from all those regions to a CloudWatch Logs log group. It is recommended that CloudTrail logs be sent to CloudWatch Logs.","remediation":"This rule ensures that Cloudtrail trails are integrated with CloudWatch Logs when customers choose to automatically configure Cloudtrail via the template.\n\nThis control is also implemented as a Config rule backed by a custom lambda function. The Config rule  DOES NOT enforce this control by configuring CloudTrail to deliver logs to CloudWatch Logs.\n\nIf the Config rule reports NonCompliance, ensure that Cloudtrail trails are integrated with Cloudwatch logs","complianceTag":"CIS for AWS v1.0.0 Section 2.4 "},{"name":"Ensure S3 bucket access logging is enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket","severity":"High","logic":"S3Bucket where policy.Statement contain [Principal.Service='cloudtrail.amazonaws.com'] should have logging.enabled='true'","description":"S3 Bucket Access Logging generates a log that contains access records for each request made to your S3 bucket. An access log record contains details about the request, such as the request type, the resources specified in the request worked, and the time and date the request was processed. It is recommended that bucket access logging be enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket.\nBy enabling S3 bucket logging on target S3 buckets, it is possible to capture all events which may affect objects within an target buckets. Configuring logs to be placed in a separate bucket allows access to log information which can be useful in security and incident response workflows.","remediation":"This rule ensures that S3 bucket access logging is enabled on the Cloudtrail S3 bucket when customers choose to automatically configure Cloudtrail via the template.\nThis control is also implemented as a Config rule backed by a custom lambda function. The config rule reports back the compliance status on whether all S3 Buckets have logging enabled. The Config rule  DOES NOT enforce this control by configuring logging on any S3 bucket.\nIt is recommended that Logging be enabled for all S3 Buckets. Configuring logs to be placed in a separate bucket allows access to log information which can be useful in security and incident response workflows. \nIf the Config rule reports NonCompliance, enable Cloudtrail S3 bucket access logging.","complianceTag":"CIS for AWS v1.0.0 Section 2.6 "},{"name":"Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs","severity":"High","logic":"CloudTrail should have kmsKeyId","description":"AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls for an account and makes those logs available to users and resources in accordance with IAM policies. AWS Key Management Service (KMS) is a managed service that helps create and control the encryption keys used to encrypt account data, and uses Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) to protect the security of encryption keys. CloudTrail logs can be configured to leverage server side encryption (SSE) and KMS customer created master keys (CMK) to further protect CloudTrail logs. It is recommended that CloudTrail be configured to use SSE-KMS.","remediation":"This rule ensures that Cloudtrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs when customers choose to automatically configure Cloudtrail via the template.\n\nThis control is also implemented as a Config rule backed by a custom lambda function. The config rule reports back the compliance status on whether CloudTrail logs are encrypted . The Config rule  DOES NOT enforce this control by enabling CloudTrail log file validation.\nConfiguring CloudTrail to use SSE-KMS provides additional confidentiality controls on log data as a given user must have S3 read permission on the corresponding log bucket and must be granted decrypt permission by the CMK policy.\n\nIf the Config rule reports NonCompliance, ensure Cloudtrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs.","complianceTag":"CIS for AWS v1.0.0 Section 2.7"},{"name":"Ensure rotation for customer created CMKs is enabled (Scored)","severity":"High","logic":"KMS where isCustomerManaged=true and deletionDate <=0 should have rotationStatus=true","description":"AWS Key Management Service (KMS) allows customers to rotate the backing key which is key material stored within the KMS which is tied to the key ID of the Customer Created customer master key (CMK). It is the backing key that is used to perform cryptographic operations such as encryption and decryption. Automated key rotation currently retains all prior backing keys so that decryption of encrypted data can take place transparently. It is recommended that CMK key rotation be enabled.","remediation":"It is recommended to rotate encryption keys to reduce the potential impact of a compromised key as data encrypted with a new key cannot be accessed with a previous key that may have been exposed.\nIf the Config rule reports NonCompliance, ensure rotation of customer created CMKs are enabled","complianceTag":"CIS for AWS v1.0.0 Section 2.8"},{"name":"Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for unauthorized API calls","severity":"High","logic":"CloudTrail should have hasSNSSubscriber='true' and metricFilters with [filterPattern isFilterPatternEqual('{ ($.errorCode = *UnauthorizedOperation) || ($.errorCode =AccessDenied*) }')]","description":"Real-time monitoring of API calls can be achieved by directing CloudTrail Logs to CloudWatch Logs and establishing corresponding metric filters and alarms. resource.","remediation":"Migrate from EC2 classic to VPCs, for example use AWS recommended steps avaliable at: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/vpc-migrate.html \r Delete old security groups after migrating the compute resources.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"'default' Security Groups should not have network policies","severity":"Medium","logic":"SecurityGroup where name='default' should have inboundRules isEmpty() and outboundRules isEmpty()","description":"The VPC default security group is automatically created, can't be deleted and by default is created with a rule allowing all inbound and outbound traffic.\nAWS and Dome9's best practice is to keep the default Security Group without any rules and avoid using it. ","remediation":"Make sure the default security group is not used and has no rules defined. \nDelete all rules that exist in the default group especially the default rules allowing any inbound and outbound traffic. ","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"Remove unused Security Groups","severity":"Medium","logic":"SecurityGroup where name != 'default' should not have networkAssetsStats contain-all [ count = 0 ]","description":"Security Groups with no attached protected assets add burden on ongoing management and might be attached to assets- increasing the risk to the organization.","remediation":"Delete all security groups which are not in use.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"RDS should not have a public network interface","severity":"Medium","logic":"RDS should not have isPublic = 'true'","description":"Databases should not be accessible to the public internet and be accessed by within a VPC in a secure manner.","remediation":"Remove the public interface, follow AWS guidlines at: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonRDS/latest/UserGuide/USER_VPC.html","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"RDS storage should be encrypted","severity":"High","logic":"RDS should have isStorageEncrypted = 'true'","description":"As a best practice, RDS should be launched encrypted storage","remediation":"Consider migrating your RDS to an at rest encrypted RDS; As heuristic the number of hosts should not exceed 256","remediation":"Limit the network exposure of the RDS service.\nMove network access to fine-grained group-to-group type of rule.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"S3 bucket CloudTrail logs should not have public accessible","severity":"High","logic":"S3Bucket where policy.Statement contain [Principal.Service='cloudtrail.amazonaws.com'] should not have ( acl.grants contain [uri like 'http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/global/%'] or policy.Statement contain [Effect='Allow' and (Principal='*' or Principal.AWS='*')])","description":"CloudTrail logs a record of every API call made in your AWS account. These logs file are stored in an S3 bucket. It is recommended that the bucket policy or access control list (ACL) applied to the S3 bucket that CloudTrail logs to prevents public access","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"Logging"},{"name":"Ensure S3 bucket access logging is enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket","severity":"High","logic":"S3Bucket where policy.Statement contain [Principal.Service='cloudtrail.amazonaws.com'] should have logging.enabled='true'","description":"S3 Bucket Access Logging generates a log that contains access records for each request made to your S3 bucket. An access log record contains details about the request, such as the request type, the resources specified in the request worked, and the time and date the request was processed. It is recommended that bucket access logging be enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket.\nBy enabling S3 bucket logging on target S3 buckets, it is possible to capture all events which may affect objects within an target buckets. Configuring logs to be placed in a separate bucket allows access to log information which can be useful in security and incident response workflows.","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"Logging"},{"name":"Ensure rotation for customer created CMKs is enabled","severity":"High","logic":"KMS where isCustomerManaged=true and deletionDate <=0 should have rotationStatus=true","description":"AWS Key Management Service (KMS) allows customers to rotate the backing key which is key material stored within the KMS which is tied to the key ID of the Customer Created customer master key (CMK). It is the backing key that is used to perform cryptographic operations such as encryption and decryption. Automated key rotation currently retains all prior backing keys so that decryption of encrypted data can take place transparently. It is recommended that CMK key rotation be enabled.","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"Ensure VPC Flow Logging is Enabled in all Applicable Regions","severity":"High","logic":"Region where ( not vpcs isEmpty() ) should have hasVpcFLowLogging='true'","description":"VPC Flow Logs is a feature that enables you to capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces in your VPC. It is recommended that MFA be enabled for all accounts that have a console password.\nEnabling MFA provides increased security for console access as it requires the authenticating principal to possess a device that emits a time-sensitive key and have knowledge of a credential.","remediation":"Follow the instructions to ensure multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enabled for all IAM users that have a console password at: https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"AWS Identity and Access Management"},{"name":"Ensure credentials (with password enabled) unused for 90 days or greater are disabled","severity":"High","logic":"IamUser where passwordEnabled='true' should have passwordLastUsed after(-90, 'days')","description":"AWS IAM users can access AWS resources using different types of credentials, such as passwords or access keys. AWS users need their own access keys to make programmatic calls to AWS from the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI), Tools for Windows PowerShell, the AWS SDKs, or direct HTTP calls using the APIs for individual AWS services. It is recommended that all access keys be regularly rotated.\n Rotating access keys will reduce the window of opportunity for an access key that is associated with a compromised or terminated account to be used. Access keys should be rotated to ensure that data cannot be accessed with an old key which might have been lost, cracked, or stolen.","remediation":"Follow the instructions to ensure unused for 90 days or greater are disabled at: https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"AWS Identity and Access Management"},{"name":"Ensure second access key is rotated every 90 days or less","severity":"High","logic":"IamUser where createDate before(-90, 'days') and secondAccessKey.isActive='true' should have (secondAccessKey.lastRotated after(-90, 'days') and secondAccessKey.lastUsedDate > secondAccessKey.lastRotated )","description":"Access keys consist of an access key ID and secret access key, which are used to sign programmatic requests that you make to AWS. AWS Access Keys provide programmatic access to a given AWS account. It is recommended that all access keys associated with the root account be removed. Removing access keys associated with the root account limits vectors by which the account can be compromised. These digest files can be used to determine whether a log file was changed, deleted, or unchanged after CloudTrail delivered the log. It is recommended that file validation be enabled on all CloudTrails.","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"Logging"},{"name":"Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs","severity":"High","logic":"CloudTrail should have kmsKeyId","description":"AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls for an account and makes those logs available to users and resources in accordance with IAM policies. AWS Key Management Service (KMS) is a managed service that helps create and control the encryption keys used to encrypt account data, and uses Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) to protect the security of encryption keys. CloudTrail logs can be configured to leverage server side encryption (SSE) and KMS customer created master keys (CMK) to further protect CloudTrail logs. The recorded information includes the identity of the API caller, the time of the API call, the source IP address of the API caller, the request parameters, and the response elements returned by the AWS service. CloudTrail uses Amazon S3 for log file storage and delivery, so log files are stored durably. In addition to capturing CloudTrail logs within a specified S3 bucket for long term analysis, realtime analysis can be performed by configuring CloudTrail to send logs to CloudWatch Logs. For a trail that is enabled in all regions in an account, CloudTrail sends log files from all those regions to a CloudWatch Logs log group. It is recommended that CloudTrail logs be sent to CloudWatch Logs.","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"Logging"},{"name":"Ensure S3 buckets are not publicly accessible","severity":"High","logic":"S3Bucket should not have ( acl.grants contain [uri like 'http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/global/%'] or policy.Statement contain [Effect='Allow' and (Principal='*' or Principal.AWS='*')])","description":"Misconfigured S3 buckets can leak private information to the entire internet or allow unauthorized data tampering / deletion","remediation":"Review the S3 bucket's ACL list and the IAM policy document. As a further protection step, Use Dome9 'Tamper Protection' (Full Protection mode) and region lock to prevent unauthorized changes to network access settings.,\r\rRefer to https://dome9-security.atlassian.net/wiki/display/DG/Edit+an+AWS+Region for more details.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"Public Instance with service 'MySQL' (TCP:3306) is exposed to the entire internet","severity":"High","logic":"Instance where isPublic=true and inboundRules contain [port <= 3306 and portTo >= 3306 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL')] should not have inboundRules contain [port <= 3306 and portTo >= 3306 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL') and scope isPublic() and scope='0.0.0.0/0']","description":"Databases store data that may be sensitive, protected by law, subject to regulatory requirements or compliance standards. This rule detects network settings that my expose an instance or a database Hadoop Name Node to a too permissive network access.","remediation":"Configure your database to only allow access in internal networks and limited access scope.,\r\rIf public interface exists, remove it and limit the access scope within the VPC only to applications or instances that requires access.,\r\rSee http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/authorizing-access-to-an-instance.html,\r\r  . This rule detects network settings that my expose an instance or a database Memcached SSL to a too permissive network access.","remediation":"Configure your database to only allow access in internal networks and limited access scope.,\r\rIf public interface exists, remove it and limit the access scope within the VPC only to applications or instances that requires access.,\r\rSee http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/authorizing-access-to-an-instance.html,\r\r  . As a further protection step, Use Dome9 'Tamper Protection' (Full Protection mode) and region lock to prevent unauthorized changes to network access settings, refer to https://dome9-security.atlassian.net/wiki/display/DG/Edit+an+AWS+Region for more details.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"Instance with unencrypted Cassandra Thrift (TCP:9160) is exposed to the public internet","severity":"High","logic":"Instance where isPublic=true and inboundRules contain [port <= 9160 and portTo >= 9160 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL')] should not have inboundRules contain [port <= 9160 and portTo >= 9160 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL') and scope isPublic() and scope numberOfHosts() >= 1]","description":"Services and databases store data that may be sensitive, protected by law, subject to regulatory requirements or compliance standards. This rule detects network settings that may expose data via unencrypted protocol over the public internet or to a too wide local scope.","remediation":"Configure your database to only allow access over encrypted protocols in internal networks.,\r\rIf public interface exists, remove it and limit the access scope within the VPC only to applications or instances that requires access.,\r\rSee http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/authorizing-access- to-an-instance.html ,\r\r . Limiting access is a good practice that prevents exploits through public interfaces or east west lateral movement.,\r\rThis rule detects network settings that allow over permissive network access for Prevalent known internal port","remediation":"Limit the access scope for Prevalent known internal port to only allow access in internal networks and limited scope.,\r\rIf public interface exists, remove it and limit the access scope within the VPC only to applications or instances that requires access.,\r\rSee http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/authorizing-access-to-an-instance.html ,\r\r . As a further protection step, Use Dome9 'Tamper Protection' (Full Protection mode) and region lock to prevent unauthorized changes to network access settings.,\r\rRefer to https://dome9-security.atlassian.net/wiki/display/DG/Edit+an+AWS+Region for more details.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"Public ELB with service 'Prevalent known internal port' (TCP:3000) is exposed to a wide public network","severity":"Medium","logic":"ELB where isPublic=true and inboundRules contain [port <= 3000 and portTo >= 3000 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL')] should not have inboundRules contain [port <= 3000 and portTo >= 3000 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL') and scope isPublic() and scope numberOfHosts() > 256 and scope !='0.0.0.0/0']","description":"Prevalent known internal port is considered a protocol that should only be exposed in private networks, for a limited scope, allowing access to only applications and services that requires access. This rule detects network settings that my expose an instance or a database Memcached SSL to a too permissive network access.","remediation":"Configure your database to only allow access in internal networks and limited access scope.,\r\rIf public interface exists, remove it and limit the access scope within the VPC only to applications or instances that requires access.,\r\rSee http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/authorizing-access-to-an-instance.html,\r\r  . As a further protection step, Use Dome9 'Tamper Protection' (Full Protection mode) and region lock to prevent unauthorized changes to network access settings, refer to https://dome9-security.atlassian.net/wiki/display/DG/Edit+an+AWS+Region for more details.","complianceTag":"Dome9 NetSec"},{"name":"ELB with unencrypted Redis (TCP:6379) is exposed to a large network scope","severity":"Medium","logic":"ELB where inboundRules contain [port <= 6379 and portTo >= 6379 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL')] should not have inboundRules contain [port <= 6379 and portTo >= 6379 and protocol in ('TCP','ALL') and scope numberOfHosts() > 256 ]","description":"Services and databases store data that may be sensitive, protected by law, subject to regulatory requirements or compliance standards. The recorded information includes the identity of the API caller, the time of the API call, the source IP address of the API caller, the request parameters, and the response elements returned by the AWS service. CloudTrail uses Amazon S3 for log file storage and delivery, so log files are stored durably. In addition to capturing CloudTrail logs within a specified S3 bucket for long term analysis, realtime analysis can be performed by configuring CloudTrail to send logs to CloudWatch Logs. For a trail that is enabled in all regions in an account, CloudTrail sends log files from all those regions to a CloudWatch Logs log group. It is recommended that CloudTrail logs be sent to CloudWatch Logs.","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"CIS for AWS Section 2.4"},{"name":"Ensure S3 bucket access logging is enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket","severity":"High","logic":"S3Bucket should have logging.enabled='true'","description":"S3 Bucket Access Logging generates a log that contains access records for each request made to your S3 bucket. An access log record contains details about the request, such as the request type, the resources specified in the request worked, and the time and date the request was processed. It is recommended that bucket access logging be enabled on the CloudTrail S3 bucket.\nBy enabling S3 bucket logging on target S3 buckets, it is possible to capture all events which may affect objects within an target buckets. Configuring logs to be placed in a separate bucket allows access to log information which can be useful in security and incident response workflows.","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"CIS for AWS Section 2.6"},{"name":"Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs","severity":"High","logic":"CloudTrail should have kmsKeyId","description":"AWS CloudTrail is a web service that records AWS API calls for an account and makes those logs available to users and resources in accordance with IAM policies. AWS Key Management Service (KMS) is a managed service that helps create and control the encryption keys used to encrypt account data, and uses Hardware Security Modules (HSMs) to protect the security of encryption keys. CloudTrail logs can be configured to leverage server side encryption (SSE) and KMS customer created master keys (CMK) to further protect CloudTrail logs. It is recommended that CloudTrail be configured to use SSE-KMS.","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"CIS for AWS Section 2.7"},{"name":"Ensure rotation for customer created CMKs is enabled (Scored)","severity":"High","logic":"KMS where isCustomerManaged=true and deletionDate <=0 should have rotationStatus=true","description":"AWS Key Management Service (KMS) allows customers to rotate the backing key which is key material stored within the KMS which is tied to the key ID of the Customer Created customer master key (CMK). It is the backing key that is used to perform cryptographic operations such as encryption and decryption. Automated key rotation currently retains all prior backing keys so that decryption of encrypted data can take place transparently. It is recommended that CMK key rotation be enabled.","remediation":"Follow AWS CIS Web Services Foundations Benchmark guidelines at https://benchmarks.cisecurity.org/tools2/amazon/CIS_Amazon_Web_Services_Foundations_Benchmark_v1.0.0.pdf","complianceTag":"CIS for AWS Section 2.8"},{"name":"Ensure a log metric filter and alarm exist for unauthorized API calls","severity":"High","logic":"CloudTrail should have hasSNSSubscriber='true' and metricFilters with [filterPattern like  '{ ($.errorcode = ..UnauthorizedOperation.. || ($.errorcode = .accessdenied..) }']","description":"Real-time monitoring of API calls can be achieved by directing CloudTrail Logs to CloudWatch Logs and establishing corresponding metric filters and alarms.
